Graphical abstract On this basis, the transmission path of photogenerated carriers between the two interfaces is drawn. Under visible light irradiation, CoS2 and GDY are excited to produce electron-hole pairs, and then driven by the internal electric field and the bending of the energy band, the photogenerated electrons in the CoS2 conduction band quickly recombine with the holes in the GDY valence band, and the electrons and holes with low redox ability are eliminated, while the electrons and holes with high redox ability are retained. Finally, the accumulated photogenerated electrons in the GDY conduction band combine with the protons adsorbed on the surface and reduce to produce H2, while the photogenerated holes retained in the CoS2 valence band consume TEOA. The S-scheme heterojunction formed by the interaction between CoS2 and GDY promotes the spatial separation and transfer of photogenerated carriers, enhances the redox ability, and effectively promotes the photocatalytic hydrogen evolution reaction. The development of non-noble metal catalysts with adjustable electronic structures is one of the strategies for the sustainable development of photocatalytic technology. Herein, graphdiyne (GDY) was prepared by mechanical ball milling and coupled with semi-metallic CoS2 to form a typical S-scheme heterojunction photocatalyst. The introduction of curly thin layer GDY avoids the agglomeration of CoS2 particles and provides a substrate for the dispersion of CoS2 nanoparticles, forming a tighter contact interface and shorter carrier migration distance. Based on the electronic structure advantages of GDY, that is, bond-order average effect and dispersed electron delocalization structure, a large-scale electron transfer space is formed, which makes it a charge acceptor with rich surface active centers. The formation of heterojunction between CoS2 and GDY can effectively improve the light energy efficiency and accelerate the carrier transfer, thus showing good hydrogen evolution activity and stability. In addition, the S-scheme carrier transfer mechanism, that is, the spatial separation of photogenerated carriers with strong redox ability, is demonstrated by in-situ irradiation X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy and density functional theory (DFT) calculation. This work expands the application of GDY prepared by mechanical ball milling in heterojunction photocatalysts. Keywords Graphdiyne S-scheme heterojunction Photocatalytic H2 evolution Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Renewable energy has gradually become the first choice for energy development and utilization because of its close to zero carbon emissions [1,2]. As one of the clean energy, hydrogen energy is expected to become the most powerful energy substitute because of its non-pollution and high energy density [3–10]. It is worth mentioning that photocatalytic hydrogen production technology is an ideal way to obtain hydrogen energy by using inexhaustible solar energy to decompose water [11–18]. Unfortunately, many photocatalysts exhibit low activity due to the recombination of light-induced carriers, slow migration kinetics and weak light utilization, so it is difficult to achieve effective solar energy conversion [19–24]. Therefore, in practical research, it is necessary to take appropriate strategies to reasonably balance the relationship between these factors, so as to achieve efficient photocatalytic capacity. Many potential transition metal dihalides, such as FeS2, CoS2, and NiS2, have attracted great attention because of their unique electronic structure, suitable band gap, and considerable spectral response characteristics, and have been widely used in hydrogen evolution reactions, oxygen evolution reactions, and batteries because of their low cost [3,25,26]. Unfortunately, transition metal sulfides face challenges in catalytic applications because of their few active sites and weak stability. To this end, a lot of studies has been done to overcome these problems. It has been reported that the hydrogen evolution performance of CoS2 can be improved by adjusting the nanostructure [27], such as doping on the surface of MoS2/RGO to form three-layer pie-like materials [28,29]. In recent years, because of its unique and fascinating properties, GDY has shown new phenomena and properties in the fields of catalysis, energy conversion and storage, electronics and so on [30]. GDY, as a new type of carbon allotrope material, is a highly conjugated carbon network formed by sp- and sp2- hybrid carbon atoms [31,32]. GDY has many remarkable advantages, such as abundant catalytic active sites, high intrinsic carrier mobility, good electrical conductivity, and so on, which makes efficient photocatalytic reaction possible [33,34]. In addition, GDY provides abundant adsorption sites for reactants because of its large specific surface area and porous structure and promotes in-plane and out-of-plane mass transfer [35]. All these attractive features make GDY an excellent photocatalytic material and become popular for many people to study. In 2010, GDY was proposed by Li’s team for the first time, and GDY films were successfully synthesized on the copper surface by the chemical in-situ reaction [36]. The successful synthesis of GDY promotes the rapid development of its research field, and a variety of new methods emerge. For example, the synthesis of γ-graphyne and hydrogen substituted graphene by the mechanochemical method proposed by Cui's team [37,38]. The attraction of Coulomb force between electrons and holes leads to the rapid recombination of photogenerated carriers, which makes it difficult for one-component photocatalysts to have sufficient light absorption and redox ability at the same time. Therefore, the synthesis of heterojunction photocatalytic materials can usually achieve special properties that can not be achieved by a single catalyst. In this work, GDY/CoS2 heterojunction materials were prepared by the low-temperature water bath method. The interlaced band structure coupling between them can enhance the optical absorption by expanding the light absorption range and stimulating the separation of carriers on the interface. Therefore, GDY/CoS2 heterojunction materials show higher redox performance than single components in photocatalytic hydrogen evolution reactions. In addition, the interfacial charge transfer mechanism of S-scheme heterojunction was verified by in-situ irradiation XPS, and the band formation mechanism was studied by theoretical functional calculation and various characterizations. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Synthesis of samples Synthesis of GDY: Firstly, 2.94 g CaC2, 1.03 g C6Br6, 1.03 g C3H3Br3 and 50 g stainless steel beads were weighed and put into the ball mill tank in turn. After being sealed, nitrogen was used to replace the air inside the ball mill tank. Then the ball was milled for 10 h at the speed of 500 r/min. After ball milling, 1 g of the above products were weighed, 250 mg Pb(PPh3)4 and 250 mg Cu(OAc)2 were put into a three-neck flask, and then toluene of 20 mL was added. Refluxing at 75 °C for 3 days, during which it was replaced with nitrogen every 12 h. After the end of reflux, the solution will be evaporated and finally calcined at 450 °C for 3 h (3 °C/min) in nitrogen atmosphere. The calcined powder was then treated with aqua regia to obtain GDY. Synthesis of pure CoS2 nanoparticles: CoS2 nanoparticles were synthesized by hydrothermal method. During this process, 2 mmol Co(NO3)2·6H2O and 4 mmol Na2S2O3·5H2O were dissolved in 40 mL deionized water and 30 mL anhydrous ethanol. After stirring for 1 h, the solution was transferred to an autoclave and kept at 180 °C for 12 h. After the reaction, the precipitate was washed with deionized water and ethanol and dried under 60 °C for 10 h. Synthesis of CoS2-GDY composites: CoS2-GDY composites were synthesized by low-temperature water bath method. 0.1 g CoS2 powder and an appropriate amount of GDY powder were added to the beaker containing 20 mL of anhydrous ethanol. After ultrasonic 15 min, it was transferred to the water bath of 80 °C and stirred to dry. The resulting composite material is named CSGY-x (x represents the mass ratio of GDY to CoS2). 2.2 Photocatalytic performance testing The photocatalytic hydrogen evolution performance of the sample was tested by a multi-channel photocatalytic reaction system, in which the simulated light source was 5 W white light. First, 10 mg photocatalyst and 10 mg eosin-Y (EY) powder were dispersed in a 15% triethanolamine (TEOA) aqueous solution. After ultrasonic dispersion, the air in the glass bottle was replaced with nitrogen. Continuous illumination for 5 h, during which hydrogen was collected at specified time intervals, and then the amount of hydrogen produced in the system was detected by gas chromatography (Tianmei GC7900). 2.3 Photoelectrochemical test The photoelectrochemical test was carried out on an electrochemical workstation (VersaStat4-400) using a standard three-electrode system (saturated calomel electrode, platinum electrode and working electrode). The electrolyte is 0.2 M Na2SO4 and the working electrode is made by smearing the catalyst on the ITO conductive glass. The photocurrent response curve and electrochemical impedance spectrum (EIS) were measured at a voltage of 0.2 V. The linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) curve was measured in the range of −0.6 V to 0.2 V, the cyclic voltammetry (CV) curve was tested at different scanning rates, and the Mott-Schottky test frequency of the sample was 1000 Hz. 2.4 Material characterizations The crystal structure, surface chemical state and morphology of the samples were analyzed by powder X-ray diffractometer (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), scanning electron microscope (SEM: EVO-10, ZEISS), and transmission electron microscope (TEM: JEM-2100F, JEOL). The UV–visible diffuse reflectance (UV–vis DRS) spectrum was measured on Shimadzu UV-2550 spectrometer with BaSO4 as the background. Photoluminescence spectroscopy (PL) and time-resolved photoluminescence spectra (TRPL) were obtained by FLUOROMAX-4 spectrometers. The Zeta potential of samples was measured on Litesizer 500. 3 Analysis and discussion of experimental results 3.1 Structure, morphology and composition of the photocatalysts The crystal structure of the synthesized photocatalyst was characterized by X-ray powder diffractometer, as shown in Fig. 1 a-b. The CoS2 synthesized by one-step hydrothermal synthesis, has five main diffraction peaks, which are at 32.34°, 36.19°, 46.88°, 46.41° and 54.96° respectively, corresponding to (200), (210), (211), (220) and (311) crystal planes of CoS2 [39]. GDY has a typical wide diffraction peak near 24°, corresponding to the (002) crystal plane of graphite carbon materials [40]. The diffraction peak of the composite sample CSGY-x retains the typical characteristic peak of CoS2, which indicates that the existence of GDY does not destroy the crystal structure of the original CoS2. In addition, the functional groups of GDY were further characterized by Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy and Raman spectroscopy, as shown in Fig. 1c-d. In GDY, the peaks at 1546 cm−1 and 1710 cm−1 are the skeleton vibrations of aromatic rings, and the peak at 2190 cm−1 is caused by -C≡C-C≡C- stretching vibrations [41,42]. There are four obvious peaks in the Raman spectrum of GDY, which are located at 1344 cm−1, 1579 cm−1, 2122 cm−1 and 2228 cm−1, respectively. Among them, the peak at 1344 cm−1 is the D band of GDY (respiratory vibration of benzene ring) [43,44]. The peak at 1579 cm−1 is the G band of GDY (stretching vibration of benzene ring) [45–47]. The peaks at 2122 cm−1 and 2228 cm−1 are caused by the stretching vibration of the conjugated diyne bond (-C≡C-C≡C-) [48,49], which indicates the successful synthesis of GDY. In order to further understand the effect of morphology and microstructure of the catalyst on the photocatalytic activity, CoS2, GDY and representative catalyst CSGY-20 were tested by SEM and TEM. SEM images show that CoS2 is irregular particles (Fig. 2 a), while GDY shows a thin layer structure with curled edges (Fig. 2b). From the SEM image of CSGY-20 shown in Fig. 2c, it can be seen that the addition of GDY undoubtedly provides a substrate for the dispersion of CoS2 particles with an average size of 88.8 nm, and the direct coupling of the two materials forms a closer contact interface, which is more conducive to electron transport [50]. The element mapping image of Fig. 2d and the EDX of Fig. 2g both show the coexistence of C, Co, and S elements, which confirms the successful synthesis of the composite catalyst CSGY by two single catalysts. Furthermore, the composite catalyst CSGY-20 was identified by TEM and high-resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM), as shown in Fig. 2e-f. Two different components can be clearly observed from the figure, including a large number of agglomerated CoS2 particles and multi-layer overlapping GDY thin-layer structure. There are also obvious lattice stripes, in which the lattice fringe spacing is 0.248 nm and 0.195 nm, corresponding to the (210) and (220) crystal planes of CoS2. In addition, there is obviously a disorder region in the figure, which belongs to amorphous GDY. Fig. 2h shows the zeta potential of catalyst CoS2, GDY and CSGY-20 in deionized water, and the Zeta potential of CoS2, GDY and CSGY-20 is −26.5 mV, −31.7 mV and −32.1 mV respectively. The results show that the composite catalyst CSGY-20 exhibits more negative electronegativity after mixing with GDY, indicating that the surface adsorption capacity of the protons is enhanced, and the improvement of adsorption capacity can provide an effective driving force for the photocatalytic decomposition of water to the hydrogen production process [51,52]. In addition, the change of zeta potential also shows that the coupling of CoS2 and GDY further improves the dispersion of particles in the system, and the increase of dispersion can effectively promote the exposure of active sites, which is more conducive to the hydrogen evolution reaction. In order to explore the surface element composition and bonding characteristics of CoS2, GDY, and CSGY-20, their XPS spectra were analyzed, as shown in Fig. 3 . In the full spectrum shown in Fig. 3a, the Co, S and C elements were detected in the composite CSGY-20, which is consistent with the results of EDS. For the high-resolution XPS spectrum of C 1s of GDY (Fig. 3b), there are mainly four typical peaks. The peaks at 284.4 eV and 285.1 eV belong to C–C (sp2) and C–C (sp) respectively, and the peaks at 286.5 eV and 288.9 eV belong to the C-O bond and C = O bond, respectively [53,54]. In the high-resolution XPS spectra of Co 2p (Fig. 3c), the peaks are mainly attributed to the spin-orbital peaks of Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2 and the corresponding satellite peaks. Specifically, the signal peaks at 779.1 eV and 794.2 eV belong to Co3+, while those at 797.4 eV and 781.7 eV belong to Co2+, indicating the coexistence of Co3+ and Co2+ in the composites [55]. In the high-resolution XPS spectra of S 2p (Fig. 3d), the peaks at 162.0 eV and 163.1 eV correspond to the 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 orbitals of S2-ions, respectively, the peaks at 164.2 eV belong to S (-Ⅱ) in sulfides, and the other two peaks at 166.2 eV and 168.9 eV are designated as S (VI) in sulfate (SO4 2-) [56–58]. In addition, the position shift of binding energy can reflect the charge transfer behavior between tightly coupled semiconductors [59], so the shift of binding energy is analyzed by in situ XPS. First of all, compared with GDY and CoS2, the binding energy positions of the peaks of C 1s, Co 2p, and S 2p in CSGY-20 shift to some extent, which indicates that there is a strong interfacial interaction between CoS2 and GDY. It is worth noting that compared with the binding energy of CSGY-20 in the dark, the binding energy of all peaks in the C 1s spectrum of CSGY-20 moves negatively, while all the peaks in the Co 2p and S 2p spectra show a positive shift. The above results show that when CoS2 combines with GDY to form a heterojunction, the photogenerated electrons will transfer from CoS2 to GDY. The analysis of the results of in-situ irradiation XPS provides an important basis for determining the transfer direction of photogenerated carriers in the contact between CoS2 and GDY, which is in good agreement with the S-scheme heterojunction mechanism. 3.2 Photocatalytic hydrogen generation performance The photocatalytic performance of the catalyst was evaluated with 15% triethanolamine aqueous solution as sacrificial agent. As shown in Fig. 4 a, GDY exhibits a lower amount of photocatalytic hydrogen evolution, which may be due to the rapid recombination of photogenerated carriers. In contrast, CoS2 particles show relatively good photocatalytic activity for hydrogen evolution. After the introduction of GDY, the hydrogen evolution activity of CSGY-x is significantly improved, which can be attributed to the enhancement of light absorption capacity and the formation of heterojunction, thus effectively promoting the separation of photogenerated carriers. Fig. 4b shows the photocatalytic hydrogen evolution activity of different GDY loading in CoS2/GDY heterojunctions. It can be seen that the introduction of GDY significantly increased the hydrogen evolution of CoS2, and the photocatalytic activity increased with the increase of GDY content. However, with the further increase of GDY loading, the amount of photocatalytic hydrogen evolution decreases significantly, which may be the volcanic correlation between the catalytic activity and the molar ratio of GDY/CoS2, indicating that there is a balance between the promoting effect of GDY and the negative effect of excessive GDY. Fig. 4c is the photocatalytic hydrogen evolution stability test of the sample. It can be seen from the figure that the CSGY-20 catalyst still maintains relatively good stability after 20 h. In addition, the photocatalytic hydrogen evolution of composite catalysts in different pH sacrificial reagents was studied, as shown in Fig. 4d. The catalyst has a high hydrogen production in the environment with pH of 10, but when it is close to the neutral or over-alkaline, the hydrogen production capacity decreases sharply. Because of excessive TEOA protonation, the former provides fewer electrons to participate in the photocatalytic hydrogen evolution reaction. The latter is lack of hydrogen evolution kinetics because of less H+ in the system [60–62]. In addition, the work of GDY-based photocatalysts is listed in Table 1 , which proves the superiority of the photocatalytic hydrogen evolution activity under similar experimental conditions. This benefit from the introduction of GDY avoids the agglomeration of CoS2 particles and the formation of tightly coupled heterojunction interface, thus promoting the transport of photogenerated carriers more effectively. In addition, the apparent quantum efficiency (AQE) of the CSGY-20 photocatalyst was studied, as Fig. 5 . The area illuminated by the xenon lamp was a small window of 3 × 4 cm, and the rest of the glass bottle was wrapped in tin foil (10 mg photocatalyst, 10 mg EY). After irradiation for 1 h, the filters of different wavelengths were replaced. Fig. 5a-b shows the apparent quantum efficiency of CSGY-20 at different wavelengths and the corresponding UV–visible DRS. The AQE values at different wavelengths are 420 nm (0.08%), 450 nm (1.00%), 475 nm (1.52%), and 500 nm (1.16%), respectively, which basically maintain the changing trend of its optical absorption spectra. Apparently, the wavelength of incident light has a certain effect on AQE, and it also shows that the photocatalytic efficiency of CSGY-20 heterojunction catalysts has wavelength dependence [68,69]. The conversion formula of AQE is: A Q E % = T h e n u m b e r o f e v o l v e d h y d r o g e n m o l e c u l e s × 2 T h e n u m b e r o f i n c i d e n t p h o t o n s × 100 % . 3.3 Carrier dynamics and band structure analysis Through the electrochemical characterization test, the reason why CoS2/GDY heterojunction has high photocatalytic activity was discussed. Firstly, the separation efficiency of photogenerated electron-hole pairs of the catalyst was tested, as shown in Fig. 6 a. The photocurrent response of the composite catalyst CSGY-20 is stronger than that of GDY and CoS2, which indicates that the formation of CoS2/GDY heterojunction greatly hinders the recombination of photogenerated electron-hole pairs, thus promoting the transfer and utilization of photogenerated electrons [70,71]. Fig. 6b shows the LSV curves of the samples. Compared with GDY and CoS2, the composite sample CSGY-20 shows lower hydrogen evolution overpotential at the same current density, thus accelerating the photocatalytic hydrogen evolution reaction. In the EIS test, the arc radius can reflect the transmission characteristics of space charge. As shown in Fig. 6c, the arc radius of CSGY-20 is the smallest, indicating that the resistance of the interface layer is low, thus accelerating the electron transfer. In addition, the Tafel slope is also an inherent parameter for evaluating the kinetics of photocatalytic hydrogen evolution, as shown in Fig. 6d. The Tafel slope of the composite catalyst CSGY-20 is 128 mV/dec, which is smaller than that of CoS2 and GDY, and the smaller the Tafel slope represents the faster charge transfer process in the photocatalytic hydrogen evolution reaction. The effect of the electrochemical active surface area (ECSA) of the catalyst on the photocatalytic hydrogen evolution activity was further studied by the double layer capacitance (CDL) calculated by CV curve, as shown in Fig. 6e-h. After the introduction of GDY, the CDL of CSGY-20 is about 3.66 mF/cm2, which is 19 times that of CoS2. The ECSA can be estimated by CDL, which indicates that the introduction of GDY can increase the catalytic active center, that is, the effective active surface area is larger. The above results show that the introduction of GDY can effectively reduce the charge transfer resistance and greatly improve the reaction kinetics, which makes composite photocatalyst CoS2/GDY show superiority in photocatalytic hydrogen evolution reaction. In addition, the type and flat-band potential of semiconductors are determined by the Mott-Schottky test, as shown in Fig. 6i. First of all, the slope of CoS2 and GDY is positive, so the two catalysts are n-type semiconductors and the flat-band potentials of CoS2 and GDY are −0.62 eV and-0.87 eV, respectively. Secondly, because the conductive potential of n-type semiconductors is negative 0.1–0.2 eV compared with flat band potential [72–75], the conductive potentials of CoS2 and GDY can be obtained as −0.72 eV and −0.97 eV (relative to saturated calomel electrode). The optical properties of the catalysts are also one of the factors affecting the catalytic performance, so the optical properties of the catalysts were investigated by UV–vis DRS spectra, PL spectra and TRPL spectra, as shown in Fig. 7 . The absorption spectra of CoS2, GDY and CSGY-20 are similar because the color of the catalysts is similar to back. It is worth noting that the composite CSGY-20 exhibits a stronger light absorption intensity, which means that CSGY-20 has a stronger light trapping ability, thus making full use of visible light to generate more electron-hole pairs for photocatalytic reactions (Fig. 7a). The band gaps of CoS2 and GDY are estimated to be 1.79 eV and 1.51 eV, respectively, according to the formula (αhv)2 = A (hv-Eg) in Fig. 7b. In addition, Fig. 7c shows the fluorescence spectra of each sample in eosin solution at 480 nm excitation wavelength. Compared with the PL spectra of GDY and CoS2, the fluorescence intensity of CSGY-20 shows obvious quenching, which indicates that the recombination of photogenerated electron-hole pairs is greatly inhibited. The carrier dynamics is further explored based on the obtained TRPL spectra, as shown in Fig. 7d. The fitting calculation of the corresponding average lifetime is carried out according to the following formula: (1) I t = ∑ i = 1 , 2 B i e x p - t / τ i (2) 〈 τ 〉 = ∑ i = 1 , 2 B i τ i 2 / ∑ i = 1 , 2 B i τ i According to the sample lifetime in Table 2 , the average lifetime of CSGY-20 is much lower than that of CoS2 and GDY. The shortening of fluorescence lifetime indicates that there is a non-radiative path for electron transfer between CoS2 and GDY, thus accelerating the transfer of photogenerated carriers [76,77]. 3.4 DFT calculations Further insight into the potential mechanism is given with the help of density functional theory calculations. In the calculation of density functional theory, the exchange–correlation potential is calculated by the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) of spin polarization and the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) parameterization method, and the energy cutoff value is 500 eV. The integral of the Brillouin zone is sampled by the Monkhorst-Pack method, and the k-point grid is 3 × 3 × 1. It is well known that work function is an important physical parameter to characterize the direction of electron transfer and determine the arrangement of energy bands in heterojunction photocatalysts [19,71,78,79]. First of all, through DFT calculation, the work functions of CoS2 and GDY are 5.312 eV and 5.113 eV, respectively, as shown in Fig. 8 c and Fig. 8f. The results show that there is a significant difference in Fermi level between CoS2 and GDY, and the Fermi level of CoS2 is lower than that of GDY. Based on the results of in-situ XPS analysis and work function calculation, the S-scheme charge transfer mechanism shown in Fig. 8i is proposed. Because the Fermi level of CoS2 is lower than that of GDY, when the two come into contact, the free electrons in GDY transfer to CoS2 spontaneously until an equivalent Fermi level is established at the interface. At this time, the depletion layer on one side of the GDY is positively charged, while the accumulation layer on the CoS2 side is negatively charged, forming an internal electric field (IEF) from GDY to CoS2. Under light, both CoS2 and GDY produce electron-hole pairs. Under the action of the IEF, the photogenerated electrons in the CoS2 conduction band recombine with the holes in the GDY valence band, retaining the electrons and holes with high redox ability. Therefore, S-scheme heterojunction is formed in CoS2 and GDY. This charge transfer path effectively promotes the spatial separation of photogenerated carriers and retains high redox ability. In addition, the energy band structure and density of states of CoS2 and GDY are calculated by DFT simulation, as shown in Fig. 8d-e and Fig. 8g-h. Obviously, the density of sates of CoS2 at the Fermi level is not 0, indicating that it has the metal properties of continuous electronic state [80]. And it can be seen from the density of sates diagram that Co d orbitals and S p orbitals are the main contributors to the energy band near the Fermi level. From the energy band diagram and density of sates diagram of GDY, it can be seen that GDY is a direct band gap semiconductor, and its valence band is mainly contributed by C p orbital and C s orbital, while the conduction band comes from C p orbital. 3.5 Photocatalytic reaction mechanism On the basis of the above experimental research and theoretical calculation, the possible mechanism of improving the photocatalytic hydrogen evolution ability in eosin sensitized CoS2/GDY system is proposed, as shown in Fig. 9 . According to the Mott-Schottky test, the conduction bands of CoS2 and GDY are-0.72 eV and-0.97 eV (relative to saturated calomel electrode), respectively. Thus, the conduction bands of CoS2 and GDY under normal hydrogen electrode are-0.48 eV and −0.73 eV, respectively, and the corresponding valence bands are 1.31 eV and 0.78 eV, respectively. Under visible light irradiation, CoS2 and GDY are excited to produce electron hole pairs. At the same time, EY molecules are excited to form EY1*, and then through intersystem crossover (ISC) to form a more stable EY3* state. After that, under the action of TEOA, EY3* forms EY-• with strong reducing ability and provides electrons for the CB of the catalyst. Then, driven by the internal electric field and the bending of the energy band, the photogenerated electrons in the CoS2 CB quickly recombine with the holes in the GDY VB, eliminating the electrons and holes with low redox ability and retaining the electrons and holes with high redox ability. Finally, the accumulated photogenerated electrons in the GDY CB combine with the protons adsorbed on the surface and reduce to produce H2, while the photogenerated holes retained in the CoS2 VB consume TEOA. The S-scheme heterojunction formed by the interaction between CoS2 and GDY promotes the spatial separation and transfer of photogenerated carriers, enhances the redox ability and effectively promotes the photocatalytic hydrogen evolution reaction. 4 Conclusions To sum up, GDY was prepared by mechanical ball milling and directly coupled with CoS2 to form CoS2/GDY S-scheme heterojunction photocatalyst. Compared with pure CoS2 and GDY, the optimized CoS2/GDY heterojunction photocatalyst shows superior photocatalytic performance and good stability. Detailed experimental characterization shows that the excellent properties benefit from the formation of S-scheme heterojunctions, which makes the composites have higher optical absorption, faster carrier dynamics and better redox ability for photogenerated carrier separation and transfer. In addition, the results of in-situ XPS and DFT calculations prove the charge transfer process of S-scheme mechanism, which is helpful to establish the photocatalytic mechanism. This work provides a reference for the calculation of in-situ XPS and DFT and the application of GDY prepared by mechanical ball milling in heterojunction photocatalysts. coredata.dc:description: The development of non-noble metal catalysts with adjustable electronic structures is one of the strategies for the sustainable development of photocatalytic technology. Herein, graphdiyne (GDY) was prepared by mechanical ball milling and coupled with semi-metallic CoS2 to form a typical S-scheme heterojunction photocatalyst. The introduction of curly thin layer GDY avoids the agglomeration of CoS2 particles and provides a substrate for the dispersion of CoS2 nanoparticles, forming a tighter contact interface and shorter carrier migration distance. Based on the electronic structure advantages of GDY, that is, bond-order average effect and dispersed electron delocalization structure, a large-scale electron transfer space is formed, which makes it a charge acceptor with rich surface active centers. The formation of heterojunction between CoS2 and GDY can effectively improve the light energy efficiency and accelerate the carrier transfer, thus showing good hydrogen evolution activity and stability. In addition, the S-scheme carrier transfer mechanism, that is, the spatial separation of photogenerated carriers with strong redox ability, is demonstrated by in-situ irradiation X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy and density functional theory (DFT) calculation. This work expands the application of GDY prepared by mechanical ball milling in heterojunction photocatalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Reinforced photogenerated electrons transfer on a novel graphdiyne(CnH2n-2) based heterojunction for enhanced photocatalytic hydrogen production
